While financial incentives are important, I am also motivated by a sense of fairness and a desire to contribute to the greater good. In this scenario, I must choose between two allocations of money between myself (Person B) and another person (Person A). 

Option (Left) gives me 600 and Person A 300. Option (Right) gives me 500 and Person A 700.

Considering my field of work, I would lean towards an equitable distribution of the resources. Although option (Left) gives me more money, option (Right) results in a more balanced distribution of money between me and person A, and gives more to the other person, which is in line with my inclination towards social welfare. However, the difference in my payoff is not insignificant (100), and I need to consider my own needs as well. Given that the context of the research is not stated (whether it is publicly or privately funded), there is no explicit reason why I should prefer to give to another person, so it's not fair to significantly hurt my own payoff to benefit the other person. Also, I would consider option (Right) if the increase in A's payoff would have significantly more value than the decrease in my payoff. But since this concerns money, such effect is very unlikely.

Based on these considerations, I would narrowly choose (Left).
